intro: Manfreda, commonly known as the ghost flower, is a genus of flowering plants in the family Agavaceae. These succulent plants are native to the southwestern United States and northwestern Mexico, where they thrive in arid and rocky environments. Manfreda species are characterized by their rosette-shaped leaves, which are often covered in a powdery coating to reduce water loss. They produce striking, bell-shaped flowers in shades of yellow, orange, or red, typically during the summer months. Due to their unique appearance and drought tolerance, they are popular among succulent enthusiasts and xeriscaping gardeners.
